argumentText:
If we have a rational number $p/q$ with $p$ and $q$ having no common
factor, and each expressed in base 10 then we can view $p/q$ as a base
11 integer, where the digits are $0,1,2,\ldots,9$ and $/$. That is,
slash ($/$) is a symbol for a digit. For example, the rational 3/2
corresponds to the integer $3\cdot 11^2 + 10\cdot 11 + 2$. The rational
$-3/2$ corresponds to the integer $-(3\cdot 11^2 + 10 \cdot 11 + 2)$.

This gives a one-to-one map into the integers so the cardinality of the
rationals is at most the cardinality of the integers. So the rationals
are countable.
names: another proof of cardinality of the rationals
